subject: Biology
objectives: Explain light reactions and Calvin cycle with key inputs/outputs
Describe glycolysis, Krebs cycle, and electron transport chain
Relate ATP production to cellular work and energy flow
Compare photosynthesis and respiration in structure and function
Apply concepts to Ghanaian agriculture and sports performance

lessons.title: Photosynthesis Process
lessons.text:
Photosynthesis occurs in **chloroplasts** and has two stages: **light reactions** and the **Calvin cycle**. In the thylakoid membranes, light energy excites electrons in **chlorophyll**, splitting water (photolysis) to release **O2**, producing **ATP** and **NADPH**. In the stroma, the Calvin cycle uses CO2, ATP, and NADPH to produce **glucose** through carbon fixation (RuBisCO), reduction, and regeneration of RuBP. Rates depend on **light intensity**, **CO2 concentration**, **temperature**, and water availability.

For Ghanaian crops like maize and cocoa, optimizing shade, spacing, and irrigation improves photosynthetic efficiency and yield. Understanding limiting factors helps farmers decide when to provide shade nets or irrigation during the dry season.

lessons.title: Cellular Respiration
lessons.text:
Cells extract energy from food through **cellular respiration**, a multi-step process: **glycolysis** (cytosol) breaks glucose into pyruvate, yielding ATP and **NADH**; the **Krebs cycle** (mitochondrial matrix) oxidizes acetyl-CoA, producing more NADH/FADH2; the **electron transport chain (ETC)** (inner mitochondrial membrane) uses these electrons to pump protons and drive **ATP synthase** to produce ATP. Oxygen is the final electron acceptor. Without sufficient oxygen, cells switch to **anaerobic respiration/fermentation**, producing lactate (in muscles) with far less ATP.

In Ghanaian athletics, sprinting relies more on anaerobic pathways for quick bursts, while long-distance running depends on sustained aerobic respiration.

lessons.title: Energy Flow in Living Systems
lessons.text:
Cells use **ATP** as the immediate energy currency. Metabolic pathways transform energy with limits set by **thermodynamics**. **Photosynthesis** stores energy in glucose; **respiration** releases it for cellular work. Efficiency varies, and heat is lost. In ecosystems, energy flows from producers to consumers; only a fraction (about 10%) transfers between trophic levels.

In Ghana’s food systems, efficient energy use relates to nutrition and crop yield, influencing health and economic outcomes.
